title: General Knowledge Quiz IX (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair across literature, history, science, geography, and tech. No sports content.

items.q: Which novel begins with the line “It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.”?
items.a: A Tale of Two Cities - Charles Dickens’s 1859 historical novel set in London and Paris

items.q: Who wrote the Southern Gothic novel To Kill a Mockingbird?
items.a: Harper Lee - 1960 Pulitzer Prize–winning novel about justice in the American South

items.q: Which Argentinian writer crafted the labyrinthine story collection Ficciones?
items.a: Jorge Luis Borges - influential 1944/1956 collection exploring infinity and metafiction

items.q: Who is the author of One Hundred Years of Solitude?
items.a: Gabriel García Márquez - 1967 landmark of magical realism set in Macondo

items.q: Which epic Old English poem features the hero who defeats Grendel?
items.a: Beowulf - the oldest surviving long poem in Old English literature

items.q: Who wrote The Picture of Dorian Gray?
items.a: Oscar Wilde - 1890/1891 novel about youth, vanity, and a cursed portrait

items.q: Which American poet penned the 1855 collection Leaves of Grass?
items.a: Walt Whitman - expansive poetry celebrating the self and democracy

items.q: Who created the detective Hercule Poirot?
items.a: Agatha Christie - prolific mystery writer whose Belgian sleuth debuted in 1920

items.q: Which Japanese author wrote Norwegian Wood?
items.a: Haruki Murakami - 1987 coming‑of‑age novel that became his breakout hit

items.q: What 1938 novel by Daphne du Maurier opens with “Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again.”?
items.a: Rebecca - a gothic tale of memory, jealousy, and identity

items.q: Which ancient city’s law code is famously inscribed on a black diorite stele?
items.a: Babylon - the Code of Hammurabi (c. 18th century BCE) carved in Akkadian cuneiform

items.q: Who united the Mongol tribes and founded the Mongol Empire in the early 13th century?
items.a: Genghis Khan - Temüjin (c. 1162–1227) established a vast trans‑Eurasian empire

items.q: Which 16th‑century seafarer led the first English circumnavigation of the globe?
items.a: Sir Francis Drake - completed his voyage 1577–1580 aboard the Golden Hind

items.q: What 1648 treaties ended the Thirty Years’ War in Europe?
items.a: The Peace of Westphalia - a diplomatic settlement reshaping sovereignty in Europe

items.q: Which revolution began in Saint‑Domingue in 1791 and led to the first Black republic?
items.a: The Haitian Revolution - culminated in Haiti’s independence in 1804

items.q: Who was the first emperor of a unified Japan in the Meiji era’s new political order (1868)?
items.a: Emperor Meiji - symbol of modernization during the Meiji Restoration

items.q: Which 19th‑century conflict saw the Charge of the Light Brigade?
items.a: The Crimean War - 1854 cavalry action memorialized by Tennyson

items.q: What 1911–1912 expedition reached the South Pole second but perished on return?
items.a: Scott’s Terra Nova Expedition - led by Robert Falcon Scott of Britain

items.q: Which 1919 pandemic is often called the Spanish flu?
items.a: Influenza pandemic of 1918–1919 - H1N1 virus causing tens of millions of deaths

items.q: Which 20th‑century leader launched China’s Cultural Revolution in 1966?
items.a: Mao Zedong - political campaign profoundly affecting Chinese society

items.q: Which branch of biology studies heredity and variation in organisms?
items.a: Genetics - from Mendelian inheritance to modern genomics

items.q: What is the term for water changing directly from solid to gas?
items.a: Sublimation - phase transition skipping the liquid state

items.q: Which vitamin deficiency causes scurvy?
items.a: Vitamin C - ascorbic acid deficiency impairs collagen synthesis

items.q: What is the largest land biome by area?
items.a: Taiga (Boreal forest) - vast coniferous forests across high northern latitudes

items.q: Which particle carries the strong nuclear force between quarks?
items.a: Gluon - the gauge boson of quantum chromodynamics

items.q: What is the most abundant mineral in Earth’s upper mantle?
items.a: Olivine - magnesium‑iron silicate common in peridotite

items.q: Which organ primarily detoxifies chemicals and metabolizes drugs in humans?
items.a: The liver - key roles include bile production and metabolism

items.q: What is the common term for dihydrogen monoxide?
items.a: Water - H₂O, essential solvent for life

items.q: Which scientist proposed the heliocentric model placing the Sun at the center?
items.a: Nicolaus Copernicus - 1543 work De revolutionibus orbium coelestium

items.q: What is the pH of gastric acid in the human stomach (approximate)?
items.a: Around 1–3 - highly acidic due to hydrochloric acid

items.q: What is the capital of Bhutan?
items.a: Thimphu - located in the western central part of the country

items.q: Which African country has its capital at Addis Ababa?
items.a: Ethiopia - seat of the African Union as well

items.q: Which strait separates Sicily from mainland Italy?
items.a: Strait of Messina - narrow passage between Sicily and Calabria

items.q: What landlocked European country uses Bern as its de facto capital?
items.a: Switzerland - Bern is the federal city

items.q: Which river forms much of the border between Texas and Mexico?
items.a: The Rio Grande - known as Río Bravo in Mexico

items.q: What is the largest lake in Africa by area?
items.a: Lake Victoria - shared by Tanzania, Uganda, and Kenya

items.q: Which Southeast Asian country was formerly known as Burma?
items.a: Myanmar - official name adopted in 1989 by the ruling junta

items.q: Which country contains the Atacama Desert?
items.a: Chile - one of the driest places on Earth

items.q: What is the capital city of Uruguay?
items.a: Montevideo - on the northern bank of the Río de la Plata

items.q: Which Asian capital is known historically as Edo?
items.a: Tokyo - renamed in 1868 when the imperial capital moved from Kyoto

items.q: Which pioneer wrote the 1843 notes describing a general‑purpose computing machine?
items.a: Ada Lovelace - notes on Babbage’s Analytical Engine, often called the first algorithm

items.q: Which 1976 paper introduced public‑key cryptography via “New Directions in Cryptography”?
items.a: Diffie and Hellman - 1976 paper laying foundations for secure key exchange

items.q: What does the acronym ASIC stand for in hardware design?
items.a: Application‑Specific Integrated Circuit - customized silicon for a task

items.q: Which company created the Macintosh computer in 1984?
items.a: Apple - introduced the GUI‑driven Macintosh on January 24, 1984

items.q: What open‑source operating system did Linus Torvalds announce in 1991?
items.a: Linux - a Unix‑like kernel that underpins many systems today

items.q: What database language is primarily used to query relational data?
items.a: SQL - Structured Query Language for managing RDBMS data

items.q: Which protocol secures web traffic by encrypting HTTP?
items.a: HTTPS - HTTP over TLS/SSL providing confidentiality and integrity

items.q: What does the ‘P’ stand for in the programming language PHP (recursive acronym)?
items.a: PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor - server‑side scripting language

items.q: Which 1995 language introduced ‘write once, run anywhere’ for the JVM?
items.a: Java - compiled to bytecode executed by the Java Virtual Machine

items.q: What technique compresses images by discarding some data to reduce size?
items.a: Lossy compression - e.g., JPEG for photographs
